structured_data.name: Meteorological drought lacunarity around the world and its classification
structured_data.method_of_access: The dataset is publicly available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3247041
structured_data.description: This dataset provides a climatic classification of drought duration around the world based on its similarity to the voids of the Cantor set. It measures dryness time structure using the n index, related to the Gini index and a Cantor-based exponent. The study used the global gridded daily Multi-Source Weighted-Ensemble Precipitation (MSWEP) dataset. The dataset covers the years 1979–2016 and has a spatial resolution of 0.5 degrees.

structured_data.name: CHIRPS (Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data)
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files, Google Earth Engine, Climateserv, FEWS NET
structured_data.description: CHIRPS is a 35+ year quasi-global rainfall dataset developed by USGS and CHC scientists. It incorporates CHPclim, 0.05° resolution satellite imagery, and in-situ station data to create gridded rainfall time series for trend analysis and seasonal drought monitoring. It supports drought monitoring efforts by USAID Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET).

structured_data.name: Global Drought Observatory (GDO) - Risk of Drought Impact for Agriculture
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query
structured_data.description: The Global Drought Observatory (GDO) provides data on the Risk of Drought Impact for Agriculture. The data is provided by the European Union, 2025, CC BY 4.0. It includes indicators such as Risk of Drought Impact for Agriculture and Meteorological Drought Tracking. The computation of the Risk of Drought Impact for Agriculture (RDrI-Agri) uses Soil Moisture Index Anomaly from July 21, 2024 onwards, and Ensemble Soil Moisture Anomaly for data before this date.

structured_data.name: Global soil moisture data derived through machine learning trained with in-situ measurements (SoMo.ml)
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF, machine-accessible metadata file (Figshare DOI)
structured_data.data_format: PDF, potentially NetCDF/GeoTIFF (implied by typical CCRA hazard data formats and 'machine-accessible metadata file')
structured_data.description: A global, long-term dataset of multi-layer soil moisture (0–10 cm, 10–30 cm, and 30–50 cm) derived through machine learning (LSTM model) trained with in-situ measurements from over 1,000 stations. The dataset, named SoMo.ml, provides daily soil moisture dynamics and is particularly useful for applications requiring time-varying soil moisture, such as anomaly detection and memory analyses. It complements existing modelled and satellite-based datasets.

structured_data.name: Global 1km daily soil moisture product from 2000 to 2020 using ensemble learning (GLASS SM)
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files via Zenodo and GLASS website
structured_data.description: A global 1km daily spatiotemporally continuous soil moisture product (GLASS SM) generated from 2000 to 2020 using an ensemble learning model (eXtreme Gradient Boosting – XGBoost). The model integrates multiple datasets including albedo, land surface temperature, leaf area index from GLASS, ERA5-Land soil moisture, ISMN in situ data, and auxiliary datasets (MERIT DEM, SoilGrids). The product aims to address the lack of long-term global soil moisture products with high spatial and temporal resolutions.

structured_data.name: TerraClimate: Monthly Climate and Climatic Water Balance for Global Terrestrial Surfaces, University of Idaho
structured_data.method_of_access: Earth Engine Snippet (API)
structured_data.description: TerraClimate is a dataset of monthly climate and climatic water balance for global terrestrial surfaces. It uses climatically aided interpolation, combining high-spatial resolution climatological normals from the WorldClim dataset, with coarser spatial resolution, but time-varying data from CRU Ts4.0 and the Japanese 55-year Reanalysis (JRA55). Temporal information is inherited from CRU Ts4.0 for most global land surfaces for temperature, precipitation, and vapor pressure, with JRA55 used for regions where CRU data had zero climate stations. JRA55 was exclusively used for solar radiation and wind speeds. The dataset additionally produces monthly surface water balance datasets using a water balance model. The dataset is provided by the University of California Merced and covers the period from 1958-01-01 to 2024-12-01, with a monthly cadence.

structured_data.name: ESA CCI Soil Moisture Dataset (version 09.1)
structured_data.method_of_access: Free and open access via CEDA catalogue download
structured_data.description: The ESA CCI Soil Moisture Dataset (version 09.1) is an upgraded iteration of the ESA Climate Change Initiative’s (CCI) soil moisture data product, derived by merging data from multiple satellite missions. It provides a globally consistent daily record of surface soil moisture. The Passive and Combined products span 1978-2023, while the Active dataset covers 1991-2023. It includes an end-to-end uncertainty budget and is used for climate studies, assessments, and applications like drought monitoring, heatwave and flood forecasting, and assessing changes in agricultural productivity.

structured_data.name: A database for characteristics and variations of global compound dry and hot events
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF, potentially data files associated with the database mentioned in the abstract
structured_data.data_format: PDF (for the article), implied database format for the actual data (not specified)
structured_data.description: This study provides a database for different characteristics, including frequency, severity, duration, and magnitude, and their variations of Compound Dry and Hot Events (CDHEs) for the period 1951–2012 over global land areas. The database evaluates changes in these characteristics, showing temporal increases over global land areas. Remarkable increases are observed in regions such as central Africa, Europe, Mediterranean regions, and northern parts of East Asia.

structured_data.name: Observation-constrained projections reveal longer-than-expected dry spells
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF
structured_data.description: This article presents observation-constrained projections that reveal a longer-than-expected increase in dry spells globally. It uses a newly proposed emergent constraint (EC) to reduce uncertainty in predictions of the longest annual dry spell (LAD), showing that the increase in LAD will be 42–44% greater than current 'mid-range' or 'high-end' future forcing scenarios indicate. By the end of the century, the global mean land-only LAD could be 10 days longer than expected. The study also identifies global regions where historical LAD biases affect projected increases and explores the role of land-atmosphere feedbacks.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Projections to the end of this century
structured_data.climate_scenario: Mid-range and high-end future forcing scenarios

The data is suitable for analysis of weather extremes and climate trends, and for rapid study of recently occurred phenomena or events. structured_data.name: Drought deciles index for spatial and temporal assessment of satellite-based precipitation datasets
structured_data.method_of_access: Purchase PDF, Access through organization
structured_data.granularity: Global (implied by satellite data, though study focuses on Iraq)
structured_data.description: This study assesses the performance of four gridded precipitation products (GPDs): APHRODITE (1983–2007), CHIRPS (1983–2017), PERSIANN (1983–2017), and TRMM, for drought monitoring using the Drought Deciles Index (DDI) at multiple time scales (1-month, 3-month, 6-month, 12-month, and 24-month) across 22 ground stations in semi-arid Iraq during 1970–2018. The study reveals the potential of GPDs for drought monitoring, with stronger performance for shorter time scales.

structured_data.name: Mapping global patterns of drought risk: An empirical framework based on sub-national estimates of hazard, exposure and vulnerability
structured_data.method_of_access: PDF download available from ScienceDirect
structured_data.description: A global map of drought risk elaborated at the sub-national administrative level for the period 2000-2014. Drought risk is assessed based on hazard, exposure, and vulnerability. Drought hazard is derived from a non-parametric analysis of historical precipitation deficits at 0.5°, exposure from aggregation of population, livestock, crop cover, and water stress indicators, and vulnerability from social, economic, and infrastructural indicators.

structured_data.name: Global-scale drought risk assessment for agricultural systems
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable article (PDF, HTML) and supplementary assets are implied through the provided links.
structured_data.description: This research article presents an integrated assessment of drought risk for both irrigated and rainfed agricultural systems at the global scale. It calculates composite hazard indicators using different drought indices based on historical climate conditions (1980–2016). Exposure was analyzed for irrigated and non-irrigated crops, and vulnerability was assessed through a socioecological-system (SES) perspective, using socioecological susceptibility and lack of coping-capacity indicators weighted by drought experts. The analysis shows heterogeneous drought risk patterns globally, with higher risk in southeastern Europe, northern, and southern Africa. The study aims to support the identification of tailored measures to reduce drought risk and increase the resilience of agricultural systems.

structured_data.name: Soil Moisture Data (NASA SPoRT-LIS, Crop-CASMA, NASA GRACE)
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query, implied data access through linked tools
structured_data.granularity: Global (implied by CONUS, Alaska, Hawaiʻi, PR/USVI options)
structured_data.description: This dataset provides current soil moisture conditions, specifically the moisture content of the top 1 meter of soil. It includes data from NASA's Short-term Prediction and Transition Center – Land Information System (SPoRT-LIS), NASA's Crop Condition and Soil Moisture Analytics tool (Crop-CASMA), and the GRACE-Based Root Zone Soil Moisture Drought Indicator. SPoRT-LIS compares current conditions to historical data from 1981–2013. Crop-CASMA shows deviation from average soil moisture conditions from 2015–present. GRACE data describes wet or dry conditions as a percentile within the period of record from 1948 to 2012. The data is provided by NASA, USDA, George Mason University, and the National Drought Mitigation Center.

The dataset is also archived and managed through the NOAA Climate Data Record program at NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI). It does not detect snow effectively.

decision_log.summary: The extracted data provides a comprehensive overview of global drought-related datasets, primarily focusing on meteorological and hydrological drought indicators (precipitation, soil moisture, drought indices). Many datasets are from highly credible sources (NOAA, ESA, Copernicus, NASA, academic institutions) and offer global coverage with varying spatial and temporal resolutions. Given the 'hazards' CCRA mode, the focus on hazard data is appropriate.

The datasets are highly relevant, come from credible sources, and offer good completeness for the 'hazards' component. No further deep dive is immediately necessary for these specific hazard datasets. The next step would be to integrate these into a CCRA framework or to initiate searches for other CCRA components (e.g., exposure, vulnerability) if they haven't been covered yet.
